description: From Middle English chime, chim, chimbe, chymbe, a shortening of chimbelle (misinterpreted as chymme-belle, chimbe-belle), from Old English ċimbala, ċimbal (“cymbal”), from Latin cymbalum.

entries.meaning: (music) A musical instrument producing a sound when struck, similar to a bell (e.g. a tubular metal bar) or actually a bell. Often used in the plural to refer to the set: the chimes.
examples: Hugo had a recording of someone playing the chimes against a background of surf noise that she found calming.
Sylvia was a chime player in the school orchestra.

entries.meaning: An individual ringing component of such a set.
examples: Peter removed the C♯ chime from its mounting so that he could get at the dust that had accumulated underneath.

entries.meaning: A small bell or other ringing or tone-making device as a component of some other device.
examples: The professor had stuffed a wad of gum into the chime of his doorbell so that he wouldn't be bothered.

entries.meaning: The sound of such an instrument or device.
examples: The copier gave a chime to indicate that it had finished printing.

entries.meaning: A small hammer or other device used to strike a bell.
examples: Strike the bell with the brass chime hanging on the chain next to it.

verbs.description: chime (third-person singular simple present chimes, present participle chiming, simple past and past participle chimed)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To make the sound of a chime.
examples: The microwave chimed to indicate that it was done cooking.
I got up for lunch as soon as the wall clock began chiming noon.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause to sound in harmony; to play a tune, as upon a set of bells; to move or strike in harmony.
(transitive) To utter harmoniously; to recite rhythmically.

examples: The other lab's results chimed with mine, so I knew we were on the right track with the research.

entries.meaning: To make a rude correspondence of sounds; to jingle, as in rhyming.
examples: It shall not keep one settled pace of time, In the same tune it shall not always chime

entries.meaning: Alternative form of chine (“edge of a cask; part of a ship; etc.”)
